awd_titl_txt: Extending Entry Models with Applications to Mergers, Bailouts, Entry Deterrence and Procurement
awd_abstract_narration:
Government policies often directly impact firms' incentives to sell products or services in a particular market.  These same incentives may also affect how well policies achieve their goals.  Existing economic models of entry take into account the effect of entry on the number and size of firms in a market.  However, some important questions about the effects of government policies on entry cannot be answered using existing models, and these models also impose sometimes unrealistic assumptions that directly affect the conclusions that can be drawn.


The research team builds new mathematical models of entry that are more realistic in key dimensions.  They will use these models to examine (i) merger policy in the airline industry; (ii) the effectiveness of a corporate bailout scheme aimed at preserving competition in timber auctions conducted by the US government; (iii) whether firms can deter entry by keeping prices low in advance of possible entry; and (iv) the possible value of using two-stage indicative bidding schemes in government procurement auctions.  The research draws upon recent advances in economic theory and econometrics to build these models.  

The project focuses on the development of methodological innovations to address important policy questions about the nature and effects of firm competition.  The results will be useful for competition policy and government procurement.  Graduate students will learn state-of-the art empirical methods and the computer code and data will be widely available.

por.por_cntn:
Firms' incentives to participate in a market can be affected by government policies and the actions of their competitors. These same incentives may also affect how well such policies achieve their goals and how incumbent market participants behave. The framework that economists use to analyze firms' participation decisions are referred to as "entry models." These models treat market structure as endogenous, meaning that it reflects the individual decisions of firms with strategic considerations for how their decisions interact with those of their competitors.

In the past few decades, economists have used entry models when considering policies that may affect or be affected by firms' incentives to enter or exit a market. However, while some research has evaluated policies allowing for endogenous entry and exit, existing modeling frameworks do not allow some important questions to be addressed and they impose restrictions that directly affect the conclusions that are drawn. 

In our research we pursue a number of different projects that model entry decisions in new and more realistic ways, particularly with regard to the information available to potential entrants at the time that they make their market entry decisions. The projects highlight the importance of modeling entry in this way when addressing important questions concerning merger policy, entry-deterring strategic behavior by incumbents, government sponsored corporate bailouts, and the design of procurement auctions. In doing so, we also develop methodological tools that can be applied in a wide range of settings. 

For example, one project analyzes the impact of corporate bailouts in the context of the Reagan administration's 1984 passage of the Federal Timber Contract Payment Modification Act (the Act), which gave assistance to firms in the timber

 industry. This bailout was a response to a dramatic fall in timber prices, due to the construction industry's contraction during the recession of the early 1980s, which left a large number of timber companies facing insolvency. An argument used to secure broad support for the Act was that, without its passage, many of these companies would have shut down and that this would have hurt future federal timber auction revenue. Using a dataset containing a sample of timber auctions (in which timber companies that harvest timber acquire it from a seller, in this case the U.S. Forest Service) from this time period, we show that incorporating the realities that there are important asymmetries between bidders (for example, some own their own timber mills), and that bidders may have differing information about how valuable a certain stand of timber is to them before undertaking costly investment to decide how much they want to bid for it, can affect the conclusions one draws about the impact of the bailout.

In another project, we consider the question of whether government agencies could improve the efficiency of their typical procurement mechanism by switching from a standard low-bid auction format, in which potential bidders can freely choose to participate, to a scheme that regulates the number of firms allowed to

 submit bids. We show that whether the latter mechanism can improve auction efficiency depends on how much information bidders have about their value of winning the contract before they engage in costly research to more precisely determine this value. When bidders have either very precise or very imprecise information about their value before undertaking more investment to determine it exactly, the regulated entry design dominates. However, when bidders' initial information is only moderately precise, a standard auction with free entry can dominate.

In two other projects we focus on the airline industry. In the first project we demonstrate that incumbent airlines on certain routes can set low prices in an effort to deter entry by new rivals, and we provide empirical evidence that the actions of major legacy carriers, when facing potential entry by low cost rival Southwest Airlines during the 1990s and early 2000s, were consistent with this strategy. We also show how such strategic pricing behavior can impact the value of Airline Service Incentive Programs, which many airports use to subsidize new entry by carriers such as Southwest Airlines. In the second project we consider the role that potential entrants into a new market play in merger analysis. Under U.S. merger policy, otherwise potentially anticompetitive mergers are allowed to

 occur if regulators deem that new entry or product re-positioning would prevent post-merger price increases. Despite the prevalence of this argument's use, notably in the airline merger review, it has received little quantitative analysis. In the project we build an empirical model of airline markets that incorporates product positioning and pricing to evaluate post-merger price increases when product re-positioning is possible. We demonstrate that allowing for these features is important for understanding the effects of recently consummated mergers in the U.S. airline industry.
